sentence: Depending on who you ask, Oracle (ORCL) is either making strong strides within the cloud -- where it competes with market leaders Salesforce.com (CRM) and Microsoft (MSFT) -- or Oracle is too far behind to ever catch up.
Regardless of your view, Oracle -- fresh off its acquisition of cloud-software company NetSuite -- is operating full speed ahead.

The Redwood City, Calif.-based tech giant is scheduled to report second quarter fiscal 2017 earnings after the closing Thursday, marking the company's first quarterly report since the $9.3 billion NetSuite deal passed a shareholder vote last month.
Once dismissing how dominant the cloud market could become was a mistake made by Oracle chairman Larry Ellison.
And Oracle stock, which has underperformed the S&P 500 index over the past couple of years, has paid for it.
However, the addition of NetSuite, one of more than $20 billion worth of M&A deals Oracle has done since 2013, underscores the lengths Ellison is willing to go to catch up.
NetSuite posted some $740 million in cloud revenue in the most-recent fiscal year.
And that revenue boost should help Oracle, achieve its goal of reaching $10 billion in cloud revenue.
The company has made high-growth cloud markets like SaaS and PaaS a priority.
And to the extent it can successfully integrate NetSuite, Oracle can move from laggard to leader in short order.
In that vein, it would be a mistake to dismiss the value Oracle shares still have today.
True, Oracle, which has missed consensus EPS estimates in the previous two quarters, still has tons of cloud grounds to make up.
But cloud and on-premise software business revenue of $6.8 billion, grew 5% year over year, while cloud SaaS and PaaS revenues of $798 million increased 77%.
Combined IaaS revenue of $969 million, Oracle's total first-quarter cloud revenue grew 59%.
Oracle only needs to improve on these number Thursday, not crush them.
For the quarter that ended November, analysts on average expect Oracle to report adjusted earnings of 60 cents per share on revenue of $9.12 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earning were 63 cents per share on $9 billion in revenue.
Oracle's cloud performance will be the main focus, however.
Anything less than $1.10 billion in total cloud revenue, which would mark 70% growth from last year's total of $649 million, will be a disappointment.

In short, Oracle's cloud performances won't impress the market in the manner of Salesforce or Amazon.com (AMZN), but the company still generates tons of cash flow, pays a decent dividend and is actively buying back shares.

Plus, at a forward P/E ratio of 14, which is about four points below the S&P 500 SPX index, Oracle stock -- at around $41 -- is a screaming bargain for shareholders willing to hold out for next 12 to 18 months.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
